26409`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/dhr/supp_info/JobSpecifications/JobSpecName/SENIOR-EMERGENCY-MANAGEMENT-COORD_8620.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`Code:  8620  Public Safety Service  Fire Service Group  Emergency Communications Series       CLASS TITLE:  Senior Emergency Management Coordinator     CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS:  Under general supervision
column2: the class  functions at the technical specialist level
column3: performing professional  emergency management work in the areas of preparedness
column5: response and recovery; and performs related duties as required.    ESSENTIAL DUTIES:  Coordinates with inter-departmental staff and  outside agencies to develop and update city-wide emergency management  plans in preparation for and response to homeland security incidents
column6: emergencies and disaster situations; ensures emergency plans comply  with federal Department of Homeland Security and state requirements  and guidelines; collaborates with other city departments and outside  agencies to develop and implement operating procedures and action  plans to effectively utilize emergency personnel and equipment during  emergency or disaster situations; oversees staff engaged in planning  and executing multi-agency training programs
column7: disaster simulation  exercises and emergency operations drills to prepare city departments  to effectively respond to emergencies; implements action plans
column8: coordinating multi-agency efforts during emergencies and city-wide  special events; provides logistical support and coordinates resources  and personnel at the scene of emergencies
column9: natural disasters and  homeland security incidents; conducts and oversees staff conducting  research regarding emergency management programs and best practices  for inclusion in emergency and disaster management plans; performs  threat and vulnerability assessments
column10: determining necessary security  and risk mitigation measures; prepares management reports relating to  personnel and resource costs associated with emergency management  programs.    RELATED DUTIES:  Drafts public informational materials and conducts  public education presentations on emergency management programs;  provides direction and guidance to lower level emergency management  coordinators.    MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS:     Training and Experience.  Graduation from an accredited college or  university with a Bachelor’s degree supplemented by two years of   experience in emergency management
column12: or fire  prevention or safety operations
column13: or an equivalent combination of  training and experience
column14: provided that the minimum degree requirement  is met.    Must have a valid State of Illinois driver’s license.     Code:  8620   Public Safety Service  Fire Service Group  Emergency Communications Series       CLASS TITLE:  Senior Emergency Management Coordinator      (Cont’d)    Knowledge
column15: Abilities and Skill.  Considerable knowledge of emergency  management response planning.  Considerable knowledge of the policies  and procedures governing emergency management operations.  Good    knowledge of project management principles and practices.  Good  knowledge of local
column16: state and federal emergency management response  plans.  Some knowledge of supervisory methods and practices.    Ability to coordinate and manage staff assigned to specialized  emergency management operations.  Ability to develop and implement  emergency plans and procedures.  Ability to prepare and maintain  program cost reports.    Good skill in coordinating emergency management activities with  responder departments and agencies.  Good skill in establishing and  maintaining effective working relationships with local
column17: state and  federal emergency management agencies.  Good skill in assessing  emergency situations and effectively allocating resources.  Good human  relations skills.  Good oral and written communication skills.    Physical Requirements.  Ability to access emergency or disaster sites.   Working Conditions.  Inside: General office environment.  Outside:  Exposure to hazardous conditions.    Equipment.  Safety equipment.  Communications equipment.  Standard  office equipment including personal computers.           NOTE: While the list of essential duties is intended to be as inclusive   as possible
column18: there may be other duties which are essential  to particular positions within the class.          September
column19: 2005  City of Chicago  Department of Personnel

column1: 19984`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2017construction/nov_2017/20171130_Rutherford_Natomas_pt2_45w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                 Sewer Main Replacement Project #7242   11/30/2017    RE:     Dear Neighbor
column2: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s “Building a New Chicago” infrastructure improvement  program
column4: I would like to provide you with information about an  upcoming sewer main construction project in your neighborhood.     By early December
column5: the Department of Water Management’s private contractor will begin  preliminary construction work at the intersections of Argyle and Natoma
column7: our in-house crews will install 750 feet of new 12-inch sewer main in N.  Rutherford Avenue (Argyle-350 feet north) and in N. Natoma Avenue (Argyle-350 feet north).  The  old sewer main dates back to 1936
column8: and needs to be replaced. DWM estimates the new sewer main  will be installed
column9: and the street will be concrete capped by spring 2018.     If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column10: please go to  wwww.BuildingANewChicago.org to register for project notifications.  Simply enter your name
column11: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.    By signing up for the project notifications
column12: you will be informed as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column13: to the installation of new  pipes
column14: to the final restoration of the street.    When we are working in the street
column15: we may close it to traffic for safety reasons
column16: but you will always  be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column17: a travel lane will be left open for  local traffic only.     We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   We are agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column18: but cars will need to be moved by the start of  the next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking as possible.    We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column19: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.     Parkway Maintenance  Before any project
column20: the Department of Water Management (DWM) takes photographs of the street  and surrounding properties. These photographs help us restore the area to its preconstruction  state. However
column21: DWM does not assume responsibility for damage to privately installed parkway  improvements
column24: flower beds and shrubbery. New sewer  construction is not complete until damaged sidewalks
column25: parkways and streets have been repaired.     Should you have any questions or concerns
column26: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column27: or call any of the following numbers:       24-Hour Service and Information Line:  311    45th  Ward Office: 773-286-4545    DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635   This project involves replacing sewer structures that may have caused disruptions to your water  service line. We recommend that as a precaution you flush your water service of any sediment
column29: including any lead to maintain water quality.      Sediment
column31: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.       (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside hose  spigot
column32: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where the  water comes into the home that is not used for drinking  water. Fully open the cold water tap and let the water run  for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any other cold water  faucets on that floor for at least 5 minutes.   (2) Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush any  taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.              If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column33: or if you would like your water  tested
column34: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water .    Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column35: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column36: taking a shower and  doing laundry.    Lastly
column37: if you don’t already have one
column38: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column39: go to  www.metersave.org.    Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.       Sincerely
column40: Randy Conner  Commissioner           Flushing Your Water Line Your water system has just been connected to a new water main. To flush your water line
column41: locate the closest available tap to where the water comes into the home
column43: laundry sink or bathtub. Fully open the cold water tap
column44: and let the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Then move to the next highest floor and repeat flushing for at least 5 minutes. Sediment and metals can collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of your faucets.  The aerator should be removed prior to flushing.   Flushing will help maintain optimum water quality by removing sediment
column47: or any lead particulates that may have come loose from your property’s water service line.  If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column48: please call us at 312-744-8190 or 311.  It is advised that you flush your water line for 5 minutes if it has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours.      Revised Graphic  Try not to use faucets for flushing that would bring the particles into the household.

column2: 2017    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #1701078    Dear Neighbor
column3: In  coordination  with  Mayor  Rahm  Emanuel’s  Building  a  New  Chicago  infrastructure  investment  program
column5: Alderman Lopez’s and Alderman Foulkes’ request
column6: I would like  to  provide  you  with  information  about  an  upcoming  water  main  construction  project  in  your  neighborhood.     In September 2017
column7: Department of Water Management crews will begin the work to install 2
column8: 661  feet of new 8-inch water main in S Washtenaw Ave from W 55th St to W 59th St.  The old water main  dates back to 1913
column9: and needs to be replaced.     If  you  would  like  to  receive  regular  email  updates  about  the  progress  of  the  project
column10: please  go  to  BuildingANewChicago.org  to  register  for  the  WaterALERT  program.    Simply  enter  your  name
column11: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.    By  signing  up  for  the  WaterALERT  emails
column12: you  will  be  notified  as  the  project  enters  each  new  construction  phase  –  from  our mobilization of  equipment  onto  the site
column13: to  the  installation of  new  pipes
column14: to the final restoration of the street.    When we are working in the street
column15: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column16: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column17: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.     We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column18: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.    We  know  that  construction  always  involves  inconveniences  and  noise.  We  will  do  everything  possible  to  maintain  your  quality  of  life  throughout  these  projects
column19: and  conducting  ourselves  as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.     Should you have any questions or concerns
column20: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column21: or call any of the following numbers:       24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311    14th Ward Office:  773-471-1414    15th Ward Office:  773-306-0837    16th Ward Office:  773-863-0220    DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635     When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column22: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column23: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column24: we may not be able to give you prior warning.    Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main     Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column25: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column27: including  any lead to maintain water quality.      Sediment
column29: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.   3   2      (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose  spigot
column30: laundry  sink  faucet  or  bathtub)  to  where  the  water  comes  into  the  home  that  is  not  used for drinking water. Fully open the cold water  tap  and  let  the  water  run  for  at  least  5  minutes.   Next  flush  any  other  cold  water  faucets  on  that  floor for at least 5 minutes.   (2) Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.          1     If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column31: please call us at 312-744-8190 or  call  311.    For  additional  advice  and  information  visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago- residents-about-lead-drinking-water.    Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column32: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column33: taking a shower and  doing laundry.      MeterSave  Lastly
column34: if you don’t already have one
column35: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column36: go to  www.metersave.org.    Thank  you  in  advance  for  your  patience  and  cooperation  during  this  important  infrastructure  improvement project.          Sincerely
column37: Randy Conner  Commissioner   Flushing Your Water Line Your water system has just been connected to a new water main. To flush your water line
column38: locate the closest available tap to where the water comes into the home
column40: laundry sink or bathtub. Fully open the cold water tap
column41: and let the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Then move to the next highest floor and repeat flushing for at least 5 minutes. Sediment and metals can collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of your faucets.  The aerator should be removed prior to flushing.   Flushing will help maintain optimum water quality by removing sediment
column44: or any lead particulates that may have come loose from your property’s water service line.  If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column45: please call us at 312-744-8190 or 311.  It is advised that you flush your water line for 5 minutes if it has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours.      Revised Graphic  Try not to use faucets for flushing that would bring the particles into the household.

column1: 7631`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2011cnstRpt/IndianaSewer20w20110708.pdf`Success`Success`4`4`Not a fillable PDF.`            WATER MANAGEMENT CUSTOMER NOTICE   July 8
column4: I am providing you with information regarding a  sewer construction project in your neighborhood. I want to be certain you are well  informed about the project
column5: and that you know where to call if you have any  questions or concerns.     Our crews will soon be installing a new sewer main in S. Indiana Avenue
column6: from E.  Garfield Boulevard to E. 57th Street. The old pipe dates back to 1889 and needs to  be replaced.     We are coordinating with Alderman Cochran’s office
column7: and he has made clear we  are to put great importance on your convenience and the quality of life in this  neighborhood through the whole term of this project. Good communication is the  key.     I have asked my staff to assemble the attached information for you and to monitor  the project closely. We know that construction always involves inconveniences  and noise. We will do everything possible to minimize inconvenience and noise  and to conduct ourselves as good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our  presence on your street.     If you have questions or comments about the project
column8: please feel free to contact  Assistant Commissioner Tom LaPorte at 312-742-1029 at any time
column9: you may leave  a message.     Thank you for your understanding and good will.     Sincerely
column10: Thomas Powers  Commissioner     cc: Alderman Willie Cochran        20th Ward                                                      INDIANA SEWER PROJECT   HISTORY        Do you wonder what was happening in 1889?  That’s the year the old sewer was installed  beneath your street.  Among other things:     Hull House              Hull House was opened by Miss Jane Addams at 800 S. Halsted
column11: helping hundreds of   Chicago immigrants gain a place of self-respect in society.     The first train load of fruit
column13: left Los Angeles for the east coast.    Benjamin Harrison won the American presidency despite Grover Cleveland’s larger   share of the popular vote.      The first concrete reinforced bridge was built.    The Chicago Auditorium opened. President Harrison made a visit.    Charlie Chaplin was born.    Bayer introduced aspirin in powder form
column14: in Germany.    The first jukeboxes were placed in bars and arcades.    The Wall Street Journal began publication.    The Oklahoma land rush officially started.         INDIANA SEWER         PROJECT DESCRIPTION     Project:  The Department of Water Management will be installing a new sewer main in S.  Indiana Avenue
column15: from E. Garfield Boulevard to E. 57th Street.       Reason:  The old pipe dates back to 1889 and needs to be replaced. The area bounded by  Garfield Boulevard on the north
column17: Prairie Avenue on the east and  Michigan Avenue on the west will benefit from improved drainage and reduced risk of  flooding.      Timing:  Work will begin shortly
column18: with completion anticipated for late November. This  includes restoration of the damaged streets/parkways. Dates may change depending on weather  and other factors. If there is any appreciable change
column19: we will notify you.    Traffic: Our excavation and the equipment involved all take up space
column22: is  the foremost consideration.  We may have some closures to “through traffic”. You will always  have access to your property.     Parking: We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed
column23: during work hours. We are  agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column24: but will have to insist that cars be moved by the  start of the next workday. We will try to preserve as much parking as we can.     CONTACT NUMBERS   24-HOUR SERVICE AND INFORMATION LINE      3-1-1            ALDERMAN WILLIE COCHRAN   773-955-5610            ASSISTANT WATER MANAGEMENT COMMISSIONER TOM LAPORTE   312-742-1029         INDIANA SEWER PROJECT    FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS        Will our sewer or water service be interrupted?  Neither should be.  But we can’t be  absolutely certain. Whenever you are doing heavy construction
column25: there are bound to be surprises.   Sometimes we find a water service from a house well away from where our records indicate it  is.  Sometimes
column26: old pipes are brittle and prone to breaking when there is the vibration of  digging.     Will I get notice if there is a shutdown?  We will try to give you notice prior to a shutdown.   But it all depends on the circumstances. If necessary
column27: we will perform the emergency shutdown  immediately and then tell you about it.  Safety and avoiding property damage are prime  considerations.    What about restoration of curb and parkway damage?  When we finish the job
column28: we will  pave the street and address curb and parkway issues.  We promise to leave your parkway and  curb at least as good as we found them.    What about improvements I’ve made in the parkway?  If there are ornamental plants
column33: we certainly try to avoid them.  The City  of Chicago
column35: cannot assume responsibility for privately made improvements.  We will  work with you to avoid any problems along these lines.    Why should I be nice about this?  We are renewing your neighborhood and helping reduce  the risk of local flooding during heavy rain.  We intend to be good neighbors
column36: although we are  aware that our work is inherently disruptive.  We will work with neighbors
column39: to ensure that this disruption is minimal and that the experience is as agreeable as  possible.

column1: 1461`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/cpb/PoliceDiscipline/17RR07.pdf`Success`Success`3`3`Not a fillable PDF.`BEFORE A MEMBER OF THE POLICE BOARD    OF THE CITY OF CHICAGO                 IN THE MATTER OF THE    RECOMMENDATION FOR DISCIPLINE OF    POLICE OFFICER BRANDON R. TERNAND
column4: CITY OF CHICAGO                         )  )   )  )  )   No. 17 RR 07     (CR No. 1058279)      REQUEST FOR REVIEW        On October 19
column6: the Office of the Police Board of the City of Chicago received from   the Chief Administrator of the Civilian Office of Police Accountability (“COPA”) a request for   review of COPA’s recommendation for discipline of Police Officer Brandon R. Ternand
column8: arising out of the investigation of Complaint Register No. 1058279 (“Request for   Review”).     The Chief Administrator recommended that the following allegations against Officer   Ternand be Sustained:   Allegation No. 1: On November 8
column10: at or about 6727 South Indiana Avenue
column12: Officer Brandon Ternand used an unreasonable and excessive amount of force when he shot  Mr. Dakota Bright.     Allegation No. 2: On November 8
column14: at or about 6727 South Indiana Avenue
column16: Officer Brandon Ternand used deadly force against Mr. Dakota Bright which was  unprovoked and unwarranted.     The Chief Administrator recommended that Officer Ternand be discharged from the Chicago   Police Department.    The Superintendent objected to the Chief Administrator’s recommendation. The   Superintendent did not concur with the Chief Administrator’s recommended findings or penalty
column17: stating that based on all the evidence presented in this case
column18: it is clear that Officer Ternand’s   actions were justified.        No. 17 RR 07  Police Officer Brandon R. Ternand  Request for Review and Opinion              According to the Certificate of Meeting and of Service submitted by the Chief   Administrator: (1) the Chief Administrator met with the Superintendent and/or his designees and   discussed this matter on October 17
column19: 2017; and (2) the Request for Review was sent via email to   the Executive Director of the Police Board on October 18
column20: 2017.      The Executive Director of the Police Board prepared and forwarded the Request for   Review file to Steve Flores
column21: the member of the Police Board who was selected on a random   basis
column22: pursuant to Article VI of the Police Board’s Rules of Procedure (“Reviewing Member”).    The Reviewing Member considered the Request for Review pursuant to Section 2-78-130(a)(iii)   of the Municipal Code of Chicago and Article VI of the Police Board’s Rules of Procedure.              OPINION   In the opinion of the Reviewing Member
column23: the objections raised in the response of the   Superintendent of Police are not sufficient to meet the burden of overcoming the Chief   Administrator’s recommendation for discipline. Based on the facts and circumstances of this   matter
column24: an evidentiary hearing before the Police Board is necessary to determine whether Officer   Ternand violated any of the Police Department’s Rules of Conduct.      Therefore
column25: pursuant to Section 2-78-130(a)(iii) of the Municipal Code of Chicago
column26: the   Chief Administrator’s recommendation for discipline of Police Officer Brandon R. Ternand
column28: shall be deemed accepted by the Superintendent of Police.            2   No. 17 RR 07  Police Officer Brandon R. Ternand  Request for Review and Opinion              DATED AT CHICAGO
column32: 2017.                                                  /s/ STEVE FLORES  Member  Police Board         Attested by:   /s/ MAX A. CAPRONI  Executive Director  Police Board             3

column1: 14574`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/dcd/2013DelegateDocs/Quick_Start_Guide-EDS.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`"Quick Start Guide  if you are new to the EDS system:   1. Go to  the right website  https://webapps.cityofchicago.org/EDSWeb      This link  must be typed  with  the  right  capitalization.   If this link  doesn't  work  for you
column2: please go to the City of Chicago  website  at   www.cityofchicago.org and in the search bar found  in the upper  right-hand  corner type  in ""EDS"". Click on the  first  search result  and scroll to  bottom of the page to the  button that  says ""Get Started On-Line"". Click on that  button......  and bookmark  the  page (add it to your  favorites).   2. Register for  the  EDS System  If you have never filled  out an on-line  EDS with  the city you can start  the registration process by clicking on ""Vendor  Registration""  found  on the left  hand side column. If someone from  your organization  has already registered
column3: you will be  linked to the  existing application  during this registration  process. If you are the  first person to  register for your organization
column6: please  be sure to type  in the  exact legal name of your organization  and enter the correct  FEIN number.  After  you fill  out the vendor  registration
column7: an account will  be generated  for your organization  and you will be sent an e-mail with  a  link
column8: user ID and a password that  will  allow  you to  log into  the  EDS system.  If you get a message that  your account requires  approval by the  EDS captain
column9: see that  person.  Both of you should read the ""Registration""  guide after clicking ""Online EDS  manuals.""   3. Login  Return to  https://webapps.cityofchicago.org/EDSWeb   In the  upper  right  hand corner  of this page
column10: there  is the  word  ""login"".  When/if you have a login name/password- you will  click on this to  login.   4. Fill out  an EDS for  a contract  If you have already  completed  your  EDS template and are bidding  on a new contract  or have been awarded  a contract
column11: you  will need to  fill  out  an EDS for  a contract. For every contract with its own  PO
column12: you will need to complete  a NEW EDS. I cannot  emphasize this enough. To do this
column13: click on ""create  new""  again but this time  indicate  that  this is for  a contract  and complete  the  questions accordingly.  Most  questions will  be pre-populated with  the answers from  your template.  If your organization  has multiple tiers  of ownership
column14: legal entity  owners  who  own more than 7.5% of your organization  will be required  to  fill  out  their  own EDS. Please  see the  help manuals and/or  videos for assistance if this is the case.   5. Print and submit your  Certificate of Filing  After  you electronically sign your EDS for  a contract
column15: click ""View  Certificate""  to  view and print your Certificate  of Filing.  Include  the Certificate  of Filing with  the  contract  materials  you return  to the City.  If you need to  reprint a certificate  later
column18: and click the  ""P"" button.   Helpful Hints:   The Online EDS has a great library  of documents  and videos to  help you troubleshoot common  questions. You can access  them  on the left  hand side column.   If you still have questions  after  reading the  instruction manuals and/or  viewing  the help videos
column19: please contact  your  contracts  person.   I   If   City  of  Chicago  Rev.11/2015   I  II                                                I  I    "

column2: 2017    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #1701057    Dear Neighbor
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column5: I would like to provide you with information  about an upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.      In late June
column6: Department of Water Management crews will begin the work to install 1
column7: 148 feet of  new 8-inch water main in N. Whipple Street (Diversey-Logan Boulevard).  The old water main  dates back to 1891
column8: and needs to be replaced.     If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column9: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column10: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.    By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column11: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column12: to the installation of new  pipes
column13: to the final restoration of the street.    When we are working in the street
column14: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column15: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column16: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.     We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column17: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.    We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column18: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.     Should you have any questions or concerns
column19: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column20: or call any of the following numbers:       24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311    32nd Ward Office: 773-248-1330    DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635      When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
